content.raw:
One thing I would like to mention here is the comparing strategy: say we have a time series of input (positions for trajectory)  
Do we want to reset the position in simulation to be equal to the input after each time step? Or we compare the whole trajectory?   

The latter is preferred, but the error will cumulate  during the whole trajectory, and I believe it could happen for the other data.
content.html:
One thing I would like to mention here is the comparing strategy: say we have a time series of input (positions for trajectory)
Do we want to reset the position in simulation to be equal to the input after each time step? Or we compare the whole trajectory?

The latter is preferred, but the error will cumulate during the whole trajectory, and I believe it could happen for the other data.

content.raw:
Maybe we could make a list of keys as user choices, since users might care different validation properties.    
If we publish each topic on, say linear velocity, force, position, orientation, etc, it might be slow if the data source  
is from real world data signal.
content.html:
Maybe we could make a list of keys as user choices, since users might care different validation properties.
If we publish each topic on, say linear velocity, force, position, orientation, etc, it might be slow if the data source
is from real world data signal.

content.raw:
I don't know much about real world sensor data, but if they have constant Hz, then we could probably pre-compute the   
time label, instead of traversal? Assume we know the time step of simulation.   
Another issue related to this is: say if the real world data is at 100 Hz (might be a weird number),  then the real world is updated   
every 0.01 second. If our simulation time step is 0.003 second, then we could probably need interpolating, but this is too detailed...
content.html:

content.raw:
Here is what I mean in an earlier comment, sometimes, it might be difficult to match the sampling rate.   
Due to the error increasing when time step is getting larger in simulation. But interpolating is a way to solve  
this, except more computationally expensive.
content.html:
Here is what I mean in an earlier comment, sometimes, it might be difficult to match the sampling rate.
Due to the error increasing when time step is getting larger in simulation. But interpolating is a way to solve
this, except more computationally expensive.

content.raw:
It would be cool to see the multiple windows pop-up with real world data and simulation data, or even plot  
[simulation data on top of real world data](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/78499864/2dgad_ncp.mp4) to see how simulation works :)   
From my experience, the force torque sensor has Windows interface, so we will count on Gazebo windows!
